context: Greeks from Cyprus have a similar history of emigration, usually to the English-speaking world because of the island's colonization by the <a0_0><b4_0>British Empire<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Waves of emigration followed the <a1_0><a2_0><b5_0><b6_0>Turkish<b5_0/><a1_0/> invasion of Cyprus<b6_0/><a2_0/> in 1974, while the population decreased between mid-1974 and 1977 as a result of emigration, war losses, and a temporary decline in fertility. After the ethnic cleansing of a third of the Greek population of the island in 1974, there was also an increase in the number of Greek Cypriots leaving, especially for <a3_0>the <b7_0>Middle East<b7_0/><a3_0/>, which contributed to a decrease in population that tapered off in the 1990s. Today more than two-thirds of the Greek population in Cyprus is urban.
